info.title: Starting, switching and terminating a &gnome; Desktop session

abstract.para: Learn how to log in to &gnome; Desktop, and how to pause or finish the session.

section.title: Starting a session
section.para: When starting your &productname; system, you first see a login screen as all users must authenticate to start a session. The authentication step helps protect your personal information and data from unauthorized access.

step.para: In the login screen, select your user name.
If your user name is not listed, click Not listed?. Then enter your user name and click Next.
Enter your password and confirm with .

note.title: Enabling Auto Login
note.para: If a computer is used by a single person only, it is possible to enable Auto Login for this particular user at system start. This can save time, but also impacts account security. Auto Login can be enabled or disabled during installation or at any time using the &yast; User and Group Management module. For security reasons, Auto Login is not recommended.

section.title: Switching the session type
section.para: To try one of the additional &gnome; session configurations or try another desktop environment, follow the steps below.

step.para: On the login screen, click your user name or enter it, as you normally would.
To change the session type, click the cog wheel icon in the lower right corner. A menu appears.
From the menu, select one of the entries. Depending on your configuration there may be different choices, but the default selection is as follows.

listitem.para: A &gnome; 4 configuration that is close to the upstream design. It focuses on interrupting users as little as possible. However, starting applications and switching between them works differently from many other desktop operating systems. It uses a single panel at the top of the screen. This session is started on Wayland.
&gnome; classic is for users who prefer a more traditional desktop experience. It is based on &gnome; 4 technologies but provides a number of changes to the user interface.
By default &productname; uses &gnome; with Wayland. Choose this option to start &gnome; on Xorg. This is also the version used in this documentation.
A basic desktop designed to use little resources. It can be used as a fallback, if other options do not work or are slow.
A minimalist desktop designed to consume as little hardware resources as possible.

step.para: Enter your password into the text box and confirm with .

section.para: After switching to another session type once, the chosen session becomes your default session. To switch back, repeat the steps above.
